elements.content: Helix represents the most essential molecular chiral symmetry at a supramolecular level. Here, a unique quasiracemate conglomerate {[Cd­(L)­I­(H2O)3]­[Cd­(HL)­I2(H2O)2]­(H2O)4} n (1, HL = N-(3,5-di­(pyridin-3-yl)-4H-1,2,4-triazol-4-yl)­nicotinamide), which crystallizes in P21 space group and consists of two different sets of helical enantiomers, has been successfully constructed. Remarkably, crystal transformations from the chiral quasiracemate 1 to two different achiral racemates {[Cd­(L)­I­(H2O)3]·(H2O)3} n (2) and {[Cd­(HL)­I2(H2O)2]­(H2O)} n (3) can be achieved controllably by introducing acid and base additives, via solvent-mediated crystal transformations.

elements.content: Helical chirality, the nonidentity of a geometric motif with its mirror image, is ubiquitous in the domain of natural substances and artificial chemicals. This fascinating chirality is usually observed in supramolecular helicates such as helical foldamers, aggregates, macromolecules, and oligomers, as well as in helical coordination polymers. Significantly, an initial asymmetry in the prebiotic world may be generated from a chance creation of minute enantiomeric excesses in helical racemates to propagate and amplify the chirality. However, by a combination of such chance events with efficient sequential autocatalytic processes, it is understandable that so many biomolecules exhibit high levels of optical purity. Although many biological macromolecules, such as DNA and proteins, possess the preferred-handed helicity to direct their sophisticated functions in living systems, spontaneous resolution of helicity at the supramolecular level is an attractive challenge for chemists. Induction of homohelicity of racemic compound or conglomerate usually requires a chiral auxiliary that is specific and effective enough to lead the generation of a particular helicity in diastereomeric excess.

elements.content: From the viewpoint of macroscopic chirality, a state of nonzero enantiomeric excess can arise spontaneously from a conglomerate through chiral symmetry breaking transition following the Calvin’s model. However, a spontaneous chiral symmetry breaking occurs scarcely in an abiotic chemical reaction, which tends to be achieved when the packed periodic environments of crystals are in the phases with the lowest translational symmetry. This nonlinear autocatalytic-recycling process probably follows the secondary nucleation in principle, which is a rather complex course and still remains unclear in theory. In the molecular chiral domain, the chirality of a racemic compound is unlocked on the basis of the chiral symmetry breaking procedure. Chirality originates from the reorganization of opposite enantiomeric building blocks in the two aspects: (i) pseudoracemate, in which the opposite enantiomers (R and S) occur in unequal proportion in the asymmetric unit of crystal lattice; (ii) quasiracemate, in which the sterically similar (isosteric) but chemically distinct enantiomers (R and S′) are present in an ordered ratio of 1:1 in the elementary cell. Understandably, the makeup of chiral symmetry could be simply achieved by modulating the R/S ratio in pseudoracemate and R/S′ constituent in quasiracemate. However, both of them have rarely been observed, mainly due to the difficulty of controllable modification of one enantiomer in a racemic compound.

elements.content: Helical coordination chains (P or M) define one of the effective and tangible expressions of chirality by showing the nonidentical mirror image, although they contain no configurationally chiral entity. A mass of elegant examples have demonstrated that by fine-tuning the ingredients of helical coordination polymers, the regulation of helical sense of these one-dimensional (1D) arrays can be accessible. However, it represents a great challenge (with no veritable example) to harmonize the balance of heterohanded helical motifs, which, however, is most significant in revealing the formation mechanism for helicity and further the origin of chirality. Herein, we report a unique example for structural conversion of helical coordination polymers, which first demonstrates the controllable crystal transformations from the chiral quasiracemate to different racemates ().

elements.content: Well-shaped yellow block single crystals of 1 were obtained from the reaction of cadmium iodide with N-(3,5-di­(pyridin-3-yl)-4H-1,2,4-triazol-4-yl)­nicotinamide (HL). As a result of single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis (see Supporting Information for details), it was illustrated that compound {[Cd­(3-L)­I­(H2O)3]­[Cd­(HL)­I2(H2O)2]­(H2O)4} n (1) crystallizes in P21 space group as a quasiracemate, the crystal structure of which contains two different sets of coordination helices, namely, [Cd­(L)­I­(H2O)3] n (P) and [Cd­(HL)­I2(H2O)2] n (M′) (). The two cadmium atoms in these two patterns are located in distinct coordination environments: one Cd­(II) atom coordinates to two pyridyl nitrogen atoms of two different L, one iodide ion, and three water molecules in a distorted octahedral geometry, and the other one is also a distorted octahedral sphere but provided by two pyridyl nitrogen atoms of two different HL, two iodide anions, and two water molecules (Table S1). As a result, two chemically different helices are formed along the 21 screw axis with the pitch of 18.217(2) Å (equal to the length of the b axis) in P and M′ helicity. The divergence between P and M′ helices is primarily attributed to the iodide number around Cd­(II) centers and self-adjustment of ligands in deprotonation (L in P while HL in M′). Notably, the adjacent same-handed helical chains are packed in the most efficient model parallel to the ab plane (8.441(1) Å of screw axes separation), leading to a dense crystal packing for homochiral two-dimensional (2D) layers. Then, the neighboring two types of chiral layers (PPP and M′M′M′) are arranged along the c direction (8.771(1) Å of screw axes separation) to construct a 3D chiral supramolecular aggregate through spontaneous resolution. Moreover, multiple weak hydrogen-bonding interactions are observed in this structure (see Figure S1 and Table S2).

elements.content: As mentioned above, a unique paradigm for quasiracemate conglomerate, which consists of two sets of different helical enantiomers, can be constructed. And thus, the most critical scientific problem arises regarding if there is a feasible way from the spontaneous resolution of a chiral crystal to its racemates with centrosymmetry. Inspired by the slight but apparent difference between the two helices (P and M′), it is reasonable to hypothesize that by modulating the deprotonation of HL and the number of iodide ions around Cd­(II), the comparable mirror-symmetry of cooperative counterparts may be appropriately restored in a harmonious state. That is to say, a genuine racemic compound may be achieved in two different ways, by modifying either one of the two helices to make them structurally compatible (P and M or P′ and M′) in a heterotactic pattern. On the basis of above consideration, NaOH was first introduced to facilitate the proton transfer of HL ligand in 1. As a result, the single-crystalline products with centrosymmetry for 2 can be generated from 1 through a solvent-mediated crystal transformation.

elements.content: In contrast, 2 shows a heterotactic structure with a 21 screw axis and crystallizes in P21/c space group (). The structure of 2 consists of two identical-ingredients 1D [Cd­(L)­I­(H2O)3] n helical motifs (P and M), where the crystallographically independent Cd­(II) ion has a distorted octahedral geometry, being coordinated by two pyridyl nitrogen atoms of two different L, one iodide anion, and three water molecules. This coordination sphere is similar to that observed in the P helix of 1. Thus, the helices with corresponding symmetry can be generated along the 21 screw axis with a pitch of 17.908(1) Å (equal to the length of the b axis). Different from that of 1, the two helices in different handness (P and M) of 2 are a chemically symmetrical pair. However, the 2D homochiral layers (PPP and MMM) in 2 are determined by the separation of same-handed helical chains (8.507(1) Å of screw axes separation) that are packed in a dense arrangement along the a axis. As a result, the heterochiral 2D layers are combined into an achiral lattice along the c direction (8.733(1) Å of screw axes separation).

elements.content: As a matter of fact, in the presence of water under a proper pH environment, one of the iodide anions around the Cd­(II) center in the M′ helix of 1 is activated, and then substituted by a water donor during the crystal transformation. As a result, the M helix is generated, and the symmetry transformation is achieved to form an achiral crystal 2. To further confirm this viewpoint, two analogues {[Cd­(L)­I­(H2O)2(CH3OH)]·(H2O)2} n (2a) and {[Cd­(L)­I­(H2O)2(CH3CN)]·(H2O)2} n (2b) were successfully produced by replacing water with methanol or acetonitrile. Notably, both one iodide ion in the M′ helix and one water ligand in the P helix are replaced with methanol or acetonitrile. Therefore, the activity of the substitution reaction lies in the activated site, but is dependent on the nature of the donor atom. Additionally, further investigation on structural transformations between the analogues 2, 2a, and 2b reveals that the crystal transformation from 2 to 2b can also be achieved, with the involvement of acetonitrile.

elements.content: As for the other procedure to fulfill the molecular symmetry transformation, hydrogen iodide is expected to be a proper candidate to increase the iodide number around the cadmium center and the protonation degree of L. Again, another typical product 3 was fortunately obtained. Similar to 2, {[Cd­(HL)­I2(H2O)2]­(H2O)} n (3) is also generated with a 21 axis and crystallizes in P21/c space group, composed of two helices with identical ingredients but different handness (P′ and M′), giving an optically inert structure (). Each Cd­(II) atom takes a distorted octahedral geometry, comprising paired nitrogen donors of HL, iodide ions, and water ligands. As expected, the pitch of helix (18.652(1) Å) is equal to the length of the b axis. The crystal stacking for 3 is as dense as that for 2, with the interhelix separation of 8.251(1) Å in the homochiral 2D layer and 8.977(1) Å between two sets of heterochiral layers.

elements.content: The results above reveal that, by the ingenious modification of the helices at a molecular level, the chiral symmetry in 1 can be transformed to the achiral lattices of 2 and 3. It is astonishing that the macroscopic NaOH or HI additive can calibrate one of the 1D helical motifs in an elaborated refinement, while preserving the other one intact in a microcosmic crystal structure. The basic skeleton of 1–3 is the neutral 1D helical strands (P/M and P′/M′), the formation of which is the result of a suitable combination of the skewed conformers of HL or L ligands (Figure S3) and cadmium centers with octahedral coordination spheres. For example, the ligands with different conformations in 1 will account for the different helicity of P and M′, which can be reflected by the dihedral angles between the pyridyl and triazolyl rings in L or HL (20.1°, 55.1°, and 69.0° for L of P as well as 14.1°, 42.4°, and 63.7° for HL of M′). Obviously, the L ligand of P displays a more distorted conformation in comparison with HL of M′ in 1. The corresponding parameters found for L of 2 are 15.4°, 50.9°, and 67.7° and for HL of 3 are 18.5°, 41.7°, and 63.1°, respectively. Therefore, the flexible nature of the ligands with the active hydrogen atoms provides the potential to achieve the crystal transformations.

elements.content: To gain some new insights into the crystallization process for the formation of helices, time-dependent experiments were carried out. The formation of 1 in solution was first investigated by 1H NMR spectra. Upon adding the reaction mixture of 1 into d 6-DMSO with stirring, the 1H NMR spectra exhibit well-resolved signals for a single ligand environment, and the ligand HL could be easily deduced from the number of signals in the spectra. With the passage of time, the resonances first remain intact for 35 min and, then, become broadened and obscure in ∼7.6 ppm. With further stirring to 3 h, the NMR resonances will be stable but significantly shifted with respect to the ligand (). Notably, the equilibration, which is stable for 10 h, is well-matched with that for 2. After ca. 10 days, the NMR resonances of 1 are observed and, not very soon, the crystalline product of 1 appears, which can be confirmed by single crystal X-ray diffraction.

elements.content: Having demonstrated the generation of chiral product 1 in solution by NMR spectra, the next procedure is to present the evidence of transformation process from 1 to 2 or 3. As shown in a, upon adding NaOH with the resultant reaction mixture of 1 into d 6-DMSO under stirring, the NMR spectra for this system were examined over time. In the first 24 h, no significant resonance shift was observed. Notably, the spectrum at 72 h displays a significant resonance shift from 7.50 to 7.40 ppm (upfield) and another shift from 9.05/9.10 to 9.15/9.20 ppm (downfield) with the peaks sharper, indicating a transformation from 1 to 2. The resonances for 2 are stable hereafter. Concomitantly, the solution color turns darker and colorless crystals of 2 can be successfully obtained after ca. 2 weeks. As for the transformation from 1 to 3, the crystals of 1 were dissolved upon the addition of HI, and then, the solution was mixed with d 6-DMSO with stirring. After ca. only 2 h, the transformation process could be completed (b) and dark yellow crystals of 3 will be observed after ca. 2 days (Figure S5).

elements.content: In summary, this work presents a unique example of a supramolecular quasiracemate, in which the ligand conformation and structural ingredient of helices are responsible for the molecular chirality of crystals. Moreover, the crystal transformations can be exquisitely rationalized by the well-defined acid or base additive. Thus, a controlled molecular chiral symmetry from break up to make up at a supramolecular level is realized by the structural transformations of these heterotactic helical coordination polymers. This unprecedented result will offer new insights into both origin and diversification of supramolecular chirality.
